sub_title: Bachelor of Data Science & Artificial Intelligence (BS)
summary: As a Data Science and Artificial Intelligence student, I am passionate about using technology to solve complex problems and create smart systems. While I have a strong background in programming and machine learning, I am always eager to learn more and expand my skillset. I have been honored to have been selected for an exchange semester to Hong Kong as well as being a part of the honor program, which have been great opportunities for me to further my education. My strong analytical skills and experience in teamwork allow me to approach projects with a problem-solving mindset and come up with innovative solutions. I am excited to continue my education and apply my knowledge to real-world problems.

education.degree_name: DKE Honours programme: Maastricht Research Based Learning (MaRBLe) 2.0

projects.title: Bachelor Thesis: Electrocardiographic Imaging of Synthesized Human Data Using Deep Learning
projects.description:
In recent years, ECG Imaging has made advances to be viable for diagnosing impending or previous heart disease, such as arrhythmias, infarctions, or other electrical abnormal activation of the heart muscle (myocardium). The technology is non-invasive and measures the activation of the myocardium at the torso using an array of usually 64 up to 256 electrodes. Moreover, the procedure is patient-specific, which requires a scan via MRI or CT to determine the geometry of the heart and torso, meaning their location, size, and rotation. Afterward, electrical activity may be reconstructed at the level of the heart using mathematical modeling techniques, commonly referred to as the inverse problem of electrocardiographic imaging.
Currently, research efforts are being made to solve this problem using machine learning techniques such as deep neural networks (DNNs), which will be the approach taken by this thesis. For this, heart surface potentials and body surface potentials must be recorded and preprocessed to be suitable as training data for a DNN.  A problem, however, is that data cannot be directly measured in humans, since this would require placing electrodes on the heart surface of the patient. 
Simulated data presents an opportunity, since it relies on correct solutions to the forward problem, therefore eliminating the possibility of errors in the data. Further, synthesized data is created with the measured geometries of past patients in mind, giving it an additional basis in reality.
The assignment during this thesis then will be to develop a model to solve the inverse problem of of ECGI without knowing the patient's heart-torso geometry. 
In conclusion, this thesis aims to utilize data normalization algorithms previously created at Maastricht University and synthesized heart surface and body surface potentials to train a neural network on solving the inverse problem of electrocardiographic imaging.

contributors.headline: Bachelor of Data Science & Artificial Intelligence (BS)

projects.title: DKE Honours programme: Maastricht Research Based Learning (MaRBLe) 2.0
projects.description:
Tasks
Working under the supervision of Cameron Browne and Kurt Driessens and in close collaboration with Filipp Dokienko and Nikola Prianikov, I am taking part in the Digital Ludeme Project. The project produces the Ludii General Game System, that offers a powerful platform to implement board games. 
Our general goal is to create a visual game designer for the Ludii language.
My personal task is to create a recommender system that offers context based recommendations to a user while creating a game.

About the Honours programme
The Department of Data Science and Knowledge Engineering offers its most talented bachelor's students the possibility to gain even more in-depth knowledge by completing their study programme with an additional honours programme. The DKE honours programme consists of two different tracks: a research track (MaRBLe 2.0) and a practical track (KE@Work). 

DKE bachelor's students get the opportunity to work on a state-of-the-art research project. Work is organised in a similar way as in professional research institutes where students work together as individual experts on a team project. Each student specialises in a task, gets assigned a team role and receives a self-contained research project. Together they work towards a common demonstration where individual research projects integrate towards a journal publication. For the individual subprojects, each student receives an individual supervisor from DKE.

contributors.headline: Bachelor of Data Science & Artificial Intelligence (BS)

projects.title: Project 1-2: A Titanic Space Odyssee
projects.description:
Titan seems to resemble Earth in its early stages, making it attractive for future space explorations. This report goes into the potential details of planning and executing a manned mission to Titan. 
To achieve this hypothetical mission, a model of the solar system has been created and the movement of celestial bodies is modeled using two ordinary differential equation solvers, a 4th order Runge-Kutta and an Euler method, as well as a root finding Newton-Raphson method. 
The goal of the mission is to simulate the path of an omni-directional probe to Titan’s orbit. Once in orbit, a landing module is dropped and its landing is simulated in a stochastic wind model. After the implementation of the ODE solvers, the settings of the mission were decided by experimenting with different step sizes and evaluating the increase in the error. 
Even though Titan’s orbit was not reached, a close approach was made. Finally, the landing of the module on Titan’s surface was successful.

contributors.headline: Bachelor of Data Science & Artificial Intelligence (BS)

projects.title: Project 1-1: Vertex Coloring
projects.description:
The vertex coloring problem is one of the most-studied NP-hard problems in computer science. As a
very influential problem, its implications can be found in all fields of computer science including
geographical map coloring, optimizing schedules, etc.
Given a graph, the goal is to assign a color c ≤ k to all vertices such that no adjacent vertices have the
same color and the number of used colors k is minimal. Many exact and heuristic approaches are
created to solve this problem, including the Backtracking, Decentralized Graphs, DSatur, Greedy, and
Welsh Powell algorithms. This study aims to obtain the most accurate and efficient algorithm to
compute the chromatic number, taking into account certain graph properties including the clique number,
number of cycles, and the highest degree.
To achieve this, the performance of the aforementioned algorithms is tested on a suite of test graphs
and compared, while bearing the special topology of each graph in mind. Hence, the final result of
these evaluations is a construct of multiple algorithms that first analyses the topology of a given graph,
and based on that, the most suited algorithm calculates the chromatic number.
From the results, it is known that Simple Decentralized Graph Colouring (SDGC) is the most accurate
and efficient exact algorithm, while the Greedy algorithm proves to be the most efficient heuristic
algorithms. However, the DSatur algorithm is the most accurate heuristic algorithm and takes the least
time to calculate a chromatic number. Since the intention of this study is the optimization of the graph
coloring approach for any given graph, property detection is used to calculate lower bounds while
DSatur is for obtaining a more accurate upper bound accordingly. Meanwhile, the DSatur algorithm
provides the upper bound for the SDGC algorithm, which then computes the exact chromatic number.

courses.name: Introduction to Data Science and Artificial Intelligence

profile_positions.description:
Selected as one out of fifteen of 150 students to for the honors program. Researched new procedure for Code Completion on small data sets by filtering results of statistical language models with intelligent Type Matching. Achieved 78% precision for predictions by using novel procedure.
One of four out of fifteen students to complete the honors program with a final grade of 8.75/10.
